Editor’s choice paper A close-up to the promoting effect of tungsten in Ce/TiO2 catalysts for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 Dedicated to Prof. Benjaram M. Reddy on the occasion of his 60th birthday. Mariam Salazar a 1 Ralf Becker b Wolfgang Grünert a ⁎ a Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-44780 Bochum, Germany Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie Ruhr-Universität Bochum Bochum D-44780 Germany b Huntsman P&A Germany, 47198 Duisburg, Germany Huntsman P&A Germany Duisburg 47198 Germany ⁎ Corresponding author at Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, P. O. Box 102148, D-44780 Bochum, Germany 1 Present address - Technip, E. Weymouth, Massachusetts-02189, U.S.A. Graphical abstract The effect of tungsten on the activity of CeOx/TiO2 catalysts for the SCR of NO by NH3 was studied with catalysts of similar composition prepared via different impregnation routes from precursors used in industry. Reaction rates were related to structural and reactivity data collected by nitrogen physisorption, XRD, TPR, TPD of NH3, FT-Raman spectroscopy, DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3, and XPS. It was observed that proper promotion of Ce-Ti oxide catalysts requires previous formation of W-O-Ti linkages: while co-impregnation resulted in the segregation of bulk W oxide, probably because of a preference of the Ce-O-Ti over the Ce-O-W interaction, interaction of tungstate with anatase appears to induce Brønsted sites associated with W. These may interact with ceria species in subsequent impregnation steps thus favoring the subsequent formation of Ce-O-W bridges. High activity requires high abundance of Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-W bridging sites accessible to the gas phase, avoiding bulk oxide phases as CeO2, and probably also TiO2 polymorphs. On the other hand, O 1s XPS signal intensity above 530.5eV often assigned to reactive oxygen (“Oα”) and surface Ce3+ concentration could not be correlated with SCR activity, neither could be the abundance of Brønsted sites, though Brønsted acidity may favor the SCR without being integrated in the active sites. Keywords NH3-SCR CeO2/TiO2 catalysts WO3 Promoting effect 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxides by NH3 is a mature technology for abating NOx in flue gas from stationary sources [1] and has meanwhile found a new application in mobile sources where NH3 is introduced in the form of urea (urea-SCR [2]). While traditional SCR catalysts composed of vanadia and tungsten oxide supported on TiO2 are very efficient in a temperature window of 300–400°C, disadvantages still remain: poor low-temperature performance, non-negligible activity towards undesired SO2 oxidation, N2O release at high temperature, and toxicity of vanadium. Therefore, much effort has been taken to reduce loadings of vanadium or to replace it by other components. While Cu- and Fe-exchanged zeolites are now important options, there are still problems with SO2 resistance of Cu zeolites and low-temperature conversion over Fe zeolites [2–5]. Oxides of many metals, e.g. Ce, Mn, Fe, Co, Cr, Cu, Ni, have been studied for SCR at low temperatures [6–11]. Ceria, which is applied in three-way catalysts due to its oxygen storage capability and redox activity [12], has been found to be a promising component for SCR catalysts [13]. Ce/TiO2 catalysts made by various techniques, e.g. impregnation [14], co-precipitation [15,16], sol-gel [17], achieved high NO conversions at excellent N2 selectivity. The most active catalysts contained, however, large percentages of Ce, some of them were made from an expensive Ti source. The potential of Ce has been related to its ease of changing between the +4 and +3 oxidation states [18]. For amorphous Ce-Ti oxides, Li et al. [19] have claimed that SCR proceeds on Ce-O-Ti bridging groups. Non-conventional Ce-based catalysts have also been reported, e.g. Mn-Ce/activated C honeycomb [20], Ce-Mn/TiO2 pillared clays [21], MnOx-CeO2/ZrO2 [22], V2O5-CeO2/ZrO2 [23], and unsupported series of Ce-Mn mixed oxides [24,25]. Mixed-oxide systems combining Ce with Ti have been also studied by B. M. Reddy et al. [26–28], however, with a focus on structural properties rather than on catalysis for NOx abatement. WO3 is a stabilizer and promoter in the traditional V2O5/TiO2 catalyst although its own SCR activity is low. Its stabilizing effect was explained by its capacity to suppress the anatase/rutile transformation [29,30], its activating effect was assigned to enhanced reducibility of V and increased acidity [31], which both play an important role in the SCR mechanism as proposed by Topsøe et al. [32]. In a study on the relation between W and V components in these catalysts we observed that vanadates exhibit a pronounced tendency to island formation on the TiO2 surface, which is strongly suppressed by tungstate [10]. The promoting effect of tungsten might therefore be related to better mixing between surface V and W oxide species. Recently, Liang Chen et al. [13,33,34] reported promising SCR activities of CeO2/TiO2 promoted by tungsten and assigned the promoting effect to the increased abundance of Ce3+ in these catalysts. Very high activities including a synergistic effect between ceria and tungsten oxides were obtained with Ce-W-Ti mixed oxides by Lei Chen et al. [35] and Shan et al. [36], again with high Ce contents. The promoting effect was assigned to facilitated surface reoxidation of the mixed Ce-O-W sites [35]. In addition, the availability of electrophilic oxygen species labeled Oα [8,36–38] was frequently claimed to be crucial for SCR activity because it favors formation of NO2 often considered as an intermediate of the SCR reaction [8,36]. Obviously, several explanations for the high activity of Ce/TiO2 catalysts and for their promotion by W are available. In the present work, we made an effort to examine some of them with a system easy to prepare from sources available on a technical scale, in particular with respect to the Ti component: a sulfate-containing titanium oxyhydrate suspension and an anatase made from it by calcination at 823K. Structural information obtained from several characterization techniques, e.g. nitrogen physisorption, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPR, NH3-TPD, in-situ DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3, and XPS was combined with catalytic reaction data. The results suggest that the role of both W and Ti is to prevent formation of the ceria lattice and achieve exposure of as many as possible Ce-O-M (M=Ti,W) bridged sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared from a titanium oxyhydrate suspension (TiO(OH)2) originating from the sulfate process, which will be labeled Ti(s). According to the manufacturer, it contained 21% of TiO2 and had a density of 1.3g/cm3. Anatase (Ti(c)) was generated from it by drying, washing and calcination at 823K in flowing dilute oxygen (20% O2/N2). Alternatively, 10 wt-% WO3/TiO2 obtained by impregnation of Ti(s) with ammonium paratungstate (APT, (NH4)10(H2W12O42)· 4H2O) and a final calcination at 823K was also used as a support and will be labeled W/Ti(s). Catalysts were made by wet impregnation using Ce(III) actetate and APT precursors in amounts to obtain 5% CeO2 and 10% WO3. Supports were contacted with the aqueous precursor solutions in a rotary evaporator at 313K for 1h before excess water was removed in vacuum at the same temperature. A monometallic CeO2/TiO2 catalyst labeled Ce/Ti(s) was obtained by impregnation of Ti(s) with the Ce precursor and subsequent calcination. For the bimetallic catalysts, impregnation sequences were varied. Thus, Ce/W/Ti(s) was prepared by impregnating W/Ti(s) with the Ce precursor, followed by a second calcination. CeW/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(c) catalysts were prepared by co-impregnating titanium oxyhydrate Ti(s) or titanium oxide Ti(c) with the W and Ce precursors, followed by calcination. All calcinations were carried out at 823K in a flow of 20% O2/He for 1h, with an initial 30min drying step at 423K accessed via a 2K/min ramp while the final calcination temperature was reached by a 5K/min ramp. The calcination temperature was adopted from industrial procedures. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Texture was characterized by N2 physisorption, measuring adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77K with a Quantachrome NOVA-2000 instrument after outgassing samples at 573K for 3h. Surface areas were evaluated from the BET model, pore volumes were determined at a relative pressure (p/p0) of 0.99. Pore size distributions (PSD) were derived from the desorption branch of the isotherms by the BJH (Barett-Joyner-Halenda) model. XRD was measured in reflection geometry with a Panalytical MPD theta-theta diffractometer, equipped with a Cu source (0.154056nm, 40kV, 40mA), 0.5° divergent and antiscatter slits, a 0.25mm high receiving slit, incident and diffracted beam 0.04rad soller slits, and a secondary graphite monochromator. Patterns were scanned at ambient temperature in the 20−70° 2θ range (step width −0.035°, dwell time −25s). Crystalline phases were identified by comparison with reference data from International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD). Crystallite sizes were derived applying the Scherrer equation to the (101) anatase reflection which is the most intense one and not influenced by neighboring signals (estimated error −5–10%). FT-Raman spectra of samples were measured with a Thermo Fisher Scientific NXT FT-Raman module combined with a Nicolet Nexus FTIR spectrometer. The system employs a near-IR laser (wavelength −1064 nm, at 0.5W) and a liquid nitrogen-cooled Ge detector. 1000 spectra at a resolution of 4 cm−1 were accumulated. Due to unsatisfactory differentiation from the Rayleigh band, spectra have been cut off at 200cm−1 . TPD of NH3 was performed in the catalytic setup (see below), analyzing NH3 concentration with an XStream X2 Analyzer (Rosemount Analytical; Emerson). A typical sample mass of 0.15g was first pretreated in He at 773K for 1h to remove adsorbates incl. loosely adsorbed oxygen species, next, ammonia was adsorbed from a flow of 1000ppm NH3/He at 373K for 1h. Physisorbed NH3 was desorbed at this temperature into a 183mlmin−1 He flow until it could no more be detected in the effluent, before TPD at 3K/min up to 773K was started. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was made with samples after calcination, ramping the temperature to 1123K at 5K/min in dilute H2 (4.5 vol-% in Ar) and maintaining this temperature until the signal reached the base line. The effluent gas was analyzed by a Hydros thermal conductivity detector (Fisher-Rosemount). DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed NH3 were collected on a Nicolet Protegé 460 spectrometer equipped with a Harrick HVC-DRP-2 high-temperature cell (praying mantis geometry, KBr windows). Samples were outgassed at 723K in 20mlmin−1 Ar for 30min, the temperature being slightly below that applied before NH3-TPD for technical reasons. They were then cooled to 373K for background registration. For adsorption, 1000ppm NH3/Ar were passed through the samples at 373K for 30min. Spectra were measured after purging physisorbed NH3 at this temperature for 1h. Compositions of near-surface layers were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a UHV system (base pressure −5×10−10 mbar) equipped with a Gammadata Scienta SES 2002 analyzer and a monochromatic Al Kα source (1486.6eV; 13.5kV; 37mA). Photoelectrons were analyzed at an energy resolution better than 0.6eV (pass energy −200eV). The surface charge was stabilized with an electron flood gun. Spectra were measured for the C 1s, O 1s, S 2p, Ti 2p, W 4d (due to signal overlap in the more familiar W 4f region) and Ce 3d regions. The binding energy scale was related to the main support line (Ti 2p3/2 =458.7eV) as a secondary reference, which is a widely used approach to escape the risks of calibration by C 1s for supported catalysts [39]. Signals were fitted using Voigt-type line shapes. Line intensities were determined by integration over a Shirley background in order to evaluate elemental ratios using sensitivity factors provided by the Casa XPS software. The metal content of the samples was analyzed by ICP-OES, using a UNICAM PU 701 spectrometer. Samples were digested by peroxide fusion, heating 25mg of them with 400mg sodium peroxide in a flame at ∼1273K in a zirconia crucible. Melted samples were dissolved with 3ml of concentrated HNO3 and diluted with water to get 50ml of solution. 2.3 Catalytic measurements Reaction rates were measured in flow regime at atmospheric pressure and temperatures between 423 and 873K using a catalytic microflow quartz reactor (4.2mm i.d.). Gas lines before and after the reactor were heated to avoid water condensation and NH4NO3 formation. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was adjusted to 300,000h−1 by loading the reactor with 25mg catalyst (45–60mesh) and feeding a total flow of 183.3mlmin−1 of a mixture consisting of 1000ppm NO, 1000ppm NH3, and 2 vol-% O2 in He. After completion of the first run, a second identical run was carried out in order to provide initial insight into changes caused by short exposure of the catalyst to high temperatures (873K). In steady state, NO, NO2 and NH3 concentrations were determined on-line using a XStream X2 Gas Analyzer (Rosemount Analytical; Emerson) which combines non-dispersive IR and UV spectrometry for quantitative analysis. Additionally, N2O and N2 were measured with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar, Pfeiffer). Conversions were calculated according to the following equation (i − NO or NH3): X i ( % ) = c i , i n − c i , o u t c i , i n × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activity In Fig. 1 , NO conversion curves of Ce(W) based catalysts are compared. They exhibit the typical conversion maximum, with an onset around 450K (except for WO3/TiO2), a peak around 700K and decay to zero conversion at 873K. The latter is due to oxidation of the NH3 reductant to NO. N2O or NO2 were not detected in any significant extent in any of the effluents obtained. At low temperatures, there was full selectivity for the SCR reaction, with NO and NH3 conversions indistinguishable in the range of experimental error. Above the NO conversion peak, NH3 conversions started to exceed NO conversions, growing, however, only moderately. Therefore, 100% NH3 conversion were not achieved even at 873K. The peculiar NH3 conversion curve of WO3/TiO2 with its pronounced decay above the NO conversion peak is apparently influenced by a deactivation phenomenon (see below). The effect of W doping on the SCR activity depends on the procedure of W incorporation. By comparison with Ce/Ti(s), activity decreased when W was introduced simultaneously irrespective whether the slurry Ti(s) or the calcined TiO2 support Ti(c) was used. Peak NO conversions decreased to ≈60% (Ce/Ti(s)−67%), the light-off temperature T50 increased to 623K (Ce/Ti(s)−580K). Opposite to co-impregnation, sequential impregnation resulted in significantly higher activity (T50– 570K, peak conversion − 76%). For the W/Ti(s) catalyst, a narrower NO conversion range was obtained, with a light-off temperature as high as 710K. Comparison of these conversion curves with those obtained in a repeated run provides a perspective of the stability of the Ce(W)/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 2 ). Exposure to 873K during the first run inflicted significant damage on both monometallic catalysts, even more severe on W/Ti(s) than on Ce/Ti(s) (Figs. 2b, a), which did not achieve an NO conversion of 60%, at a light-off temperature increased by 85K. The even more drastic deactivation of W/Ti was a surprise because WO3 is known for its favourable influence on the texture of titania [29]. Therefore, a high stability of this catalyst was expected. Promotion of Ce/TiO2 by W significantly increased stability. This applies also to the catalysts made by co-impregnation (Figs. 2c and e), although an adverse effect of temperature was still observed with them. Opposed to this, Ce/W/TiO2 was completely stable under the prevailing conditions, exhibiting even slightly higher NO conversions in the second run, though probably within the error margins (Fig. 2d). 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Textural properties and chemical analysis Chemical analyses, BET surface areas, pore volumes, transition metal (TM) coverages and resulting Ce/W atomic ratios are given in Table 1 , pore size distributions (PSD) are shown in Fig. 3 (for adsorption isotherms – see Fig. S1a). For the monometallic catalysts, the states after the second run are reported as well, the related isotherms and PSDs can be found in Figs. S1 and S2 (cf. electronic supporting information). Table 1 shows the WO3 content near the targeted 10 wt-% while the CeO2 content fluctuates between 3.8 and 5.0 wt-%. Sulfate originates from the production process, but the range of its variation is unexpectedly wide, in particular the upper limit of 2.2 wt-% in W/Ti(s). Calcination may result in some sulfate loss, in particular if transition metal species compete with the sulfate for surface sites. Indeed, with only one exception (Ce/Ti(s)), introduction of supported species onto the Ti(c), Ti(s), and W/Ti(s) supports with subsequent calcination always resulted in decreased sulfate contents. Transition metal coverage was estimated assuming monolayer surface coverage of 7 atoms per nm2 [40] for Ce and of 4.1 atoms for W [41]. Total coverage has been reported in Table 1, which can be differentiated using the Ce/W atomic ratios. While the bimetallic catalysts are near or even above the monolayer limit, the monometallic ones are clearly below, in particular Ce/Ti(s). The dried titanium oxyhydrate Ti(s) has very small pores. Its PSD peaks still in the micropore range (2nm) where BJH is inaccurate. Its calcination results in a large loss of BET surface area, and the resulting Ti(c) has a wide PSD centered around 4–5nm (Fig. 3), which is shifted to even larger pore sizes by introduction of Ce and W. With Ce and W deposited on Ti(s), the PSD of the catalysts remained much narrower than that of Ti(c), which confirms the stabilizing effect of these components. The PSD of Ce/Ti(s), which has the highest BET surface area among these catalysts (Table 1) peaks at the lowest pore sizes: apparently the stabilizing effect of Ce is more intense than that of tungstate (Fig. 3). This is confirmed by the BET surface areas of catalysts made from Ti(s) (Table 1). Indeed, Ce/Ti(s) has a larger BET surface area than W/Ti(s), and consecutive impregnation+calcination to get Ce/W/Ti(s) did not change the surface area any more. In addition, co-impregnation of ceria and tungstate resulted in a larger BET surface area than impregnation of W alone. On the other hand, co-impregnation of ceria and tungstate onto Ti(c) decreased its BET surface area far below the values obtained with the Ti(s) support. This may suggest that the interaction between support and supported species is more intense when the highly reactive slurry Ti(s) is used, which might explain why catalysts made from this supports come out with the higher BET surface areas. The effect of the catalytic runs on catalyst texture as studied by the monometallic samples was very small: BET surface areas and pore volumes did not change significantly (footnote to Table 1). Variations in the pore size distributions (Figs. S1, S2) imply, however, that this is due to a compensation of smaller changes in different pore-size ranges. Thus, pore-volume was lost at low sizes (with Ce/Ti(s) surprisingly accompanied by a shift of the distribution peak towards the micropore region) while larger pores became more abundant. 3.2.2 X-ray diffraction XRD patterns of the Ce(W)-based catalysts shown in Fig. 4 are dominated by peaks originating from anatase. The typical peaks of fluorite-structured CeO2 at 2Θ=28.6, 33.1, 47.5 and 56.3° were not present in any of the diffractograms. The ceria species are either highly dispersed or constitute an amorphous phase. Signals arising from monoclinic WO3 were clearly detected in the catalysts made by co-impregnation, but were absent in W/Ti(s) and Ce/W/Ti(s). Due to signal overlap, crystal size determination was not attempted for WO3. A comparison between signals in the overlapping peak range around 34° belonging to WO3 and the (200) signal of anatase can, however, be used to qualitatively compare the amounts of segregated WO3. This ratio was 0.11 for CeW/Ti(c) and 0.15 for CeW/Ti(s), which suggests there is somewhat more segregated WO3 in the latter sample. Different widths of the anatase reflections in Fig. 4 suggest differences in the particle sizes, which are tabulated in Table 1. Except for one case (CeW/Ti(c)), the differences are not large and near to the error limit. On the other hand, the decreased anatase crystal size of Ce/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(s) as compared to the reference Ti(c) is in agreement with BET data, and may therefore provide another support for the conclusion that ceria acts as an inhibitor of anatase crystallization as proposed by Shan et al. [15]. The large crystal size and lower BET area of CeW/Ti(c) may be understood as a resulting from twofold calcination (of support and final catalyst). In Fig. S3, diffractograms of monometallic catalysts before and after two catalytic runs are compared. While there are no additional phases after catalysis, unexpected changes in the line width can be observed: apparently, the crystallite size increased in W/Ti(s) as expected, but decreased in Ce/Ti(s). The reason for the latter result is still unclear. 3.2.3 Raman spectroscopy FT-Raman spectra obtained from our samples are presented in Fig. 5 . In all fresh catalysts (Fig. 5a), the bands at 395, 516, and 639cm−1 indicative of the anatase phase are well developed (further signals at 150 and 197cm−1 have been cut off). In agreement with evidence from XRD, none of the spectra contained any signal of rutile or of CeO2. In particular, the intense peak at 465cm−1 [42] characteristic of the CeO2 fluorite structure was always absent. In further agreement with XRD, signals typical of monoclinic WO3 were detected in the spectra of CeW/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(c) − two intense peaks at 715 and 806cm−1, and further signals in the 200–350cm−1 region [43]. In Fig. 5b, Raman spectra of monometallic catalysts are compared before and after catalysts. There is no evidence for new transition metal oxide phases after catalysis. However, the spectrum of W/Ti(s) was of very low intensity and showed up on an intense background, which might be due to deposition of a fluorescent species. 3.2.4 Temperature programmed reduction TPR profiles of our catalysts and of reference samples and data on hydrogen consumption are given in Fig. 6 and Table 2 . In the profile of Ti(s), an asymmetric signal was observed, apparently caused by sulfate reduction. Its width and structure indicates heterogeneity of the sulfate species [10]. According to Jung and Grange [44], their reduction does not result in a well-defined product, rather, SO3-x (x=0, 1) and H2S can be released simultaneously. Sulfate reduction has a significant impact on the TPR profiles of Ce(W)-catalysts. It should be noted that the measured H2 consumption of Ce/Ti(s) was larger than the expected one for Ce(IV) reduction (see Table 2). Reduction of Ce-containing catalysts started at lower temperatures (Fig. 6), which suggests that Ce reduction accelerates sulfate reduction. Indeed, in Ce/Ti(s), the sulfate peak at ≈830K was completely missing. In contrast, reduction of W/Ti(s) started in the same temperature range as the sulfate signal in TiO2, hence, tungstate had no influence on sulfate reduction. The reduction of unsupported CeO2 produces two signals originating from reduction of Ce4+ in surface layers (low temperature) and in the bulk CeO2 lattice (high temperature) [12]. Supported CeO2 (Ce/Ti(s)) exhibited in a single asymmetric reduction peak instead, slightly upshifted from the low-temperature signal of CeO2, but followed by a tailing up to very high temperatures. This suggests that the Ce4+ species, though somewhat stabilized by the support, are almost completely available to low-temperature reduction, i.e. Ce dispersion is very high. Unsupported WO3 was reduced above 800K with several sharp and overlapping signals. Supported on TiO2, it became more reducible and produced three peaks. The low-temperature onset is very similar to that of sulfate on TiO2, but the two low-temperature peaks, which were not resolved in a similar experiment in [10], certainly arise from superimposed reduction of sulfate and of W(VI) to W(IV). The high-temperature signal above 973K was assigned to reduction of W(IV) to W metal [10,45,46]. In the profiles of the bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 6), features arising from sulfate, Ce4+, and W6+ reduction overlapped in a way which prevents safe differentiation of their origins. Based on the profiles of monometallic catalysts, one may, however, certainly assign high-temperature consumption to reduction of W(IV) to W(0) while all components may contribute to low-temperature consumption. Profiles of catalysts made by sequential and by co-impregnation were clearly differentiated by the width of their features. Peaks of the former were very broad, indicating wide ranges of stability as would be expected from an intense interaction with a high surface-area support. At 1100K, the signal was still far from the baseline. Profiles of catalysts resulting from co-impregnation exhibited steeper features which may arise from material in loose contact with the support. At 1100K, the signal was considerably closer to the baseline in these profiles than in that of Ce/W/Ti(s). To substantiate these observations, H2 consumptions have been quantified to compare them with consumptions expected from sample composition based on reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, and of W6+ to W(0): 2 CeO2 +H2 →Ce2O3 +H2O WO3 +3 H2 →W+3 H2O Results are collected in Table 2. As expected, the reduction degree of CeO2 remained low, but that of bulk WO3 was not complete at 1100K either. Consumption of Ce/Ti(s) was corrected by subtracting a contribution from sulfate estimated from the actual sulfate content (Table 1) and the consumption obtained with Ti(s). The resulting reduction degree of Ce4+ is obviously too high, which may arise from several reasons: errors in elemental analysis of Ce and/or S, different sulfate reduction chemistry (and, hence, H2 consumption) in presence and in absence of Ce, error by a baseline drift (cf. course of baseline parallel to zero around 1000K, Fig. 6). While the actual reason(s) will not be easily identified, it is certainly safe to conclude that Ce4+ is reduced in the low-temperature region to a large extent if not completely. The latter has been assumed together with the correction for sulfate mentioned above to allow for a coarse estimate of W reduction degrees as presented in Table 2. These data shows nicely that W becomes almost completely reduced in the catalysts made by co-impregnation, while its final reduction degree in Ce/W/Ti(s) appears to be even lower than that in the W/Ti(s) support employed for its preparation. This suggests that there is also an interaction between Ce species and tungstate: the reduction behavior of the latter is clearly influenced by the presence of the former. 3.2.5 Effect of W on catalyst acidity The density of acidic sites has been probed with TPD of NH3. Profiles are presented in Fig. S4, total acid site quantities are given in Table 1. At the first glance, the profile shapes seem to be very similar. When ammonia desorbing below 473K is assigned to weak sites and above 600K to strong sites, the profiles indicate a prevalence of weak acid sites over strong ones although the strong sites appear to be somewhat more abundant in W/Ti(s). A closer look shows however, that this applies also for Ce/Ti(s) as can be deduced from comparison of its profile with the blown-up profile of W/Ti(s) in Fig. S4. Apparently, these additional strong sites are destroyed when the support is fully covered. The acid site concentrations of Ce/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(s), which have the same sulfate content, scale with the BET surface area (Table 1). Probably, stronger sites related to the support were replaced by weaker sites on the added tungstate. IR spectra in the NH stretching region of NH3 adsorbed on these catalysts are presented in Fig. 7 . They show an intense band at 1603cm−1 arising from NH3 at Lewis sites and a weak band at 1673cm−1 due to NH4 + protonated by Brønsted sites of the support (symmetric deformation mode). At lower wave numbers, the asymmetric deformation mode is expected around 1440cm−1, but this range appears to be affected by baseline effects shifting the signal in a region between 1420 and 1450cm−1. The symmetric deformation mode at 1673cm−1 is very weak or absent in some cases and most intense on W/Ti(s) and on Ce/W/Ti(s) prepared from the latter. The intensity of the asymmetric mode below 1450cm−1 agrees with these trends. The signals at 1603 and 1673cm−1 have been fitted with two components, from which the (B/L) intensity ratios listed in Table 1 have been derived. Although the ratio for Ti(s) is not available for comparison, the high B/L ratio of W/Ti(s) suggests that the additional acidity induced by the tungstate species is largely of Brønsted type. This is confirmed by the comparison between CeW/Ti(s) and Ce/W/Ti(s): in the former, for which we found a lower dispersion of the WO3 component (see sections 3.2.2 and 3.2.3), Brønsted sites could not even be clearly identified. The lower B/L ratio of Ce/W/Ti(s) as compared with W/Ti(s) indicates that B sites are covered or, more likely, consumed during the introduction of the ceria component. As they are related to the tungstate groups, this result suggests that a close relation between tungstate and ceria species and at the same time a high dispersion of ceria sites has been created. Although the catalysts made by co-impregnation exhibit an even lower B/L ratio than Ce/W/Ti(s), any assignment to consumption of tungstate-related Brønsted sites in this case would interfere with our structural data showing that in these samples, tungstate failed to interact properly with the anatase surface. Therefore the low concentration of these sites predominantly arises from to their rare formation due to poor tungstate/anatase interaction rather than to their consumption, which results in a lower abundance of interactions between ceria and tungsten oxide moeities. 3.2.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Information about the composition of the near-surface region and on oxidation states of the catalyst components was obtained by XPS. Ce 3d and O 1s regions are shown in Fig. 8 . Binding energies and atomic ratios in the near-surface region are summarized in Table 3 and compared with the corresponding ratios in the bulk (in parentheses). The binding energies correspond to expectations for W6+ and S6+. The values of Ce 3d5/2 exhibit some scatter, which is due to small binding energy differences between Ce oxidation states involved and limited energy resolution due to limitations in measurement time. The Ce 3d line (Fig. 8a) has a complex structure comprising several satellites, where the spectral components v0 and v’ of Ce 3d5/2 (for Ce 3d3/2– u0 and u’) are characteristic for the Ce3+ state while v, v”, v”’ (Ce 3d5/2) and u, u”, and u”’ (Ce 3d3/2) arise from Ce4+. The u”’ satellite originates from Ce4+ exclusively, without superposition of any other line, and can be therefore used to estimate the percentage of Ce4+ in the total of Ce inventory, avoiding errors generated from the complex deconvolution of Ce 3d signal shape [47]. This percentage, which is reported in Table 3, is derived from ratio between areas of the u”’ component and the total Ce 3d signal in the unknown sample to the same ratio in a reference CeO2 assumed to contain ≈100% Ce4+. This analysis revealed considerable differences in the Ce oxidation states in our catalysts. While Ce tended to be trivalent in the bimetallic systems, Ce4+ and Ce3+ were present in equal amounts in Ce/Ti(s). This is different from observations in the (V-) Ce-TiOx system where vanadium was found to influence the oxidation state of Ce insignificantly [26]. After two catalytic runs, Ce4+ had completely disappeared also in the latter catalyst. Different from some other reports, our earlier experience with XPS of Ce(IV) containing systems [48] does not suggest a strong influence of Ce(IV) photoreduction in UHV on the reduction degrees in samples of the present composition. Even if this process were significant, the spectra nevertheless indicate strong differences in stability of Ce(IV) in presence or absence of W. Ce/Ti ratios in the near-surface region (Table 3) were always higher than the corresponding bulk values, indicating that all catalyst surfaces are enriched in Ce. Opposed to this, surface W/Ti ratios were equal to or even below the bulk ones for CeW/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(c), which confirms conclusions from Raman and XRD on the aggregation of the tungstate phase. W/Ti(s) and Ce/W/Ti(s) both exhibited a strong W surface enrichment as expected. The S/Ti ratios from XPS (Table 3) on the whole paralleled the bulk sulfate concentrations (Table 1). Reflecting a surface density rather than a bulk concentration, such ratios are influenced by the BET surface area. Although smaller physical surface area should increase the S/Ti ratio, the high value obtained for CeW/Ti(c) is surprising. Most spectacular, however, is the complete absence of the S 2p signal in W/Ti(s) after two catalytic runs, completely different from Ce/Ti(s) where the S/Ti ratio was only slightly decreased (Table 3). Opposed to changes in surface sulfur concentration, the W/Ti ratio of W/Ti(s) was completely unchanged after catalysis while the Ce/Ti ratio in Ce/Ti(s) decreased drastically. The O 1s peak (Fig. 8b) had always a minor shoulder to higher binding energies, which may be assigned to surface OH groups [49]. However, other assignments associate signals with higher binding energy to adsorbed oxygen, which is more reactive and might accelerate SCR by its capacity to favor NO2 formation from NO [8,36]. While O2 − and O− species have been mentioned as candidates [8,36–38], some authors classified them as subsurface species [37]. We have fitted the O 1s signals by three components corresponding to lattice oxygen (526.9eV, Oβ) and up to two signals at 530.9-531.3eV and 531.9-532.2eV representing the shoulder (Oα, see example in Fig. 8b), and the resulting Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratios are given in Table 3 as well. With respect to this ratio, Ce/Ti(s) exceeds the other catalysts significantly while the two mixed catalysts prepared with Ti(s) are comparable. The lowest Oα content was obtained for W/Ti(s), but the value found for CeW/Ti(c) was only slightly higher. 4 Discussion The most obvious result of this study is the failure of the co-impregnation route in the preparation of active CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts. Only a sequential route, with ceria impregnation onto a calcined WO3/TiO2 support resulted in a catalyst which outperformed monometallic CeO2/TiO2 in terms of both activity and stability. This deviates from observations made earlier in a study with a different impregnation route and a different titania support [13]. Such contradiction shows that minor variations in the preparation route and materials used may change results significantly. The segregation of WO3 may be a consequence of the high transition metal coverage. However, no segregation was found in the sequentially prepared Ce/W/Ti(s) with a very similar metal coverage. Apparently, the presence of both metal precursors during impregnation makes the difference. From solubility data (1.5g APT/100ml H2O [50], only 0.35g cerium acetate/100ml H2O [51] at 20°C), one would, however, rather expect a Ce compound to be precipitated during solvent evaporation. The segregation of WO3 instead suggests that the interaction of ceria with the anatase surface is stronger than that of tungstate. As this holds even for a route where surface concentrations during the deposition step were rather small due to high surface area of the support (Ti(s)), this primacy of the Ce-O-Ti interaction seems to prevail also during calcination: when the surface area is decreased, ceria expels tungstate from the surface, similar as recently reported for the competition between vanadate and tungstate [52,53]. In agreement with this observation, Ce was also found to prevent anatase particle growth as reported earlier [49], even to a larger extent than tungstate. Our TPR studies (Section 3.2.5) gave indirect evidence for a more intense interaction between ceria and tungstate in Ce/W/Ti(s) than in the catalysts made by co-impregnation. According to the IR results, Brønsted sites associated with surface tungstate species were consumed when ceria was deposited (Section 3.2.5, Fig. 7). Therefore, the creation of a surface phase with both W and Ce well dispersed results also in the abundant formation of Ce-O-W interactions identified as favourable for activity by several groups [13,36,54]. The rather high activity of Ce/Ti(s) confirms that the Ce-O-Ti structure can support high SCR rates as well, as reported earlier [15,19,55]. However, this structure deteriorated already under relatively mild thermal stress which was readily survived by the Ce/W/Ti(s) catalyst. In our characterization effort, we examined several properties of the catalysts which are often related to the activity of SCR catalysts, e.g. BET surface area, Ce oxidation state, acidity, content of Oα species. For neither of them, a clear relation with activity could be established. This holds in particular for acidity and content of Oα species. The total amount of acidic sites was highest for Ce/Ti(s), not for the most active Ce/W/Ti(s). On the other hand, the latter stands out by the highest B/L ratio of bimetallic catalysts (Table 1). However, catalysts prepared by co-impregnation still exhibited significant SCR activity although Brønsted activity could not be detected in them. Therefore, Brønsted sites may favor SCR activity, but are not involved in the active ensemble. The abundance of labile oxygen identified as the Oα species is another property often related to SCR activity. In our case, Oα was most abundant in Ce/Ti(s) (cf. Table 3), which was, however, not the most active catalyst. The values for Ce/W/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(s) were comparable, their activities were not. CeW/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(c), which exhibited identical performance in the low-temperature region, differed in their Oα content. Finally, while the poorest catalyst (W/Ti(s)) came out with the lowest Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio, CeW/Ti(c), which had a similar abundance of Oα, exhibited a drastically better performance. These observations do not support a relation between Oα and SCR activity. We consider this due to the fact that XPS intensities in the corresponding binding energy region can arise from different species. OH groups will definitely appear in this region, and if the sample contained electrophilic oxygen species, which might have similar binding energies, they would be stable in UHV only if trapped below the surface. The activity of this kind of catalyst was also assigned to a preference of Ce(III) over Ce(IV) in the tungsten-promoted materials, taking into account the consideration that Ce(III) would offer more coordinative unsaturation for adsorbing reactants that Ce(IV). Indeed, in our most active catalyst (Ce/W/TiO2), Ce was exclusively in the +3 oxidation state (Table 3), while its oxidation state was higher in the less active Ce/Ti(s). However, the reduction degree of Ce was different in the co-impregnated catalysts (CeW/Ti(s) and CeW/Ti(c)) while their behaviour in the low-temperature range relevant for activity discussions was identical (Fig. 1). There were several catalysts with Ce exclusively in the +3 oxidation state, which exhibited different activities. One of them was Ce/Ti(s) after the second run. The changed Ce valence state of this catalyst suggests that analysis after catalysis would be a more appropriate basis for conclusions on this problem, but we skipped this analysis for the remaining samples most of which contained the Ce in the +3 state right from the start. Finding Ce exclusively in the +3 state in catalysts of rather different activity, we rule out the Ce(III)/Ce(IV) ratio as a parameter influencing activity to a significant extent. This is also supported by the observation that in some Ce-W-Ti oxide catalysts described in literature, which were significantly more active than our materials [15,36], the percentage of Ce(IV) was much larger than on our samples On the basis of these results, we consider high dispersion of Ce and W components and mutual interaction between them as crucial parameters with respect to SCR activity and stability. It is well known that the redox activity of CeO2 is confined to the outmost surface layer at low temperatures. Accessibility of lattice oxygen is strongly enhanced by introducing other elements into the lattice (e.g. in CeZrOx mixed oxides, also in WO3 deposited onto CeO2 [56]). Therefore, a high abundance of Ce-O-M bridges accessible from the gas phase is probably an important structural motif of a successful catalyst. On the basis of our results Ce-O-W bridges may be considered more active than Ce-O-Ti bridges, but the difference should be not dramatic. Indeed, in highly active co-precipitated Ce-(W-)Ti oxide catalysts reported in literature [15,36], the promotion by W was significant but not huge. The advantage of co-precipitation (or of the sol-gel route) may be the higher disorder in the resulting phases. Ce-O-Ti bridges may be more reactive if the Ti is not part of a well-stabilized solid anatase phase. The drastic deactivation of W/Ti(s) was a surprising by-product of this study. The reason could not be clearly identified on the basis of available data. There was no loss in the BET surface area (Table 1, footnote b), but the pore-size distributions shown in Fig. S2 suggest that this results from cancellation of different influences, i.e., the pore system was perturbed during catalysis. Most significantly, W/Ti(s) totally lost sulfate during catalysis, very different from Ce/Ti(s) (Table 3), and its scattering properties deteriorated, which resulted in a poor quality of its Raman spectrum (Fig. 5b). A tentative explanation may start with the idea that the loss of sulfate below 873K can occur only by a redox process resulting in SO2. Reductants available are NH3, NO, and N-containing adsorbates with N oxidation state below +5. The different behaviour of W/Ti(s) and Ce/Ti(s) with respect to sulfate could be understood only with the latter. Their coverage degree might be low for a catalyst active in SCR while they might accumulate on the surface of W/Ti(s), reducing sulfate, and possibly also W(VI) species. The resulting high coverage of stable nitrates or an attack on the tungstate-support interaction might further impair the low SCR activity. The former might influence the Raman background by fluorescence, the latter might perturb the support surface creating, for instance, roughness deteriorating scattering properties and, hence, quality of Raman spectra. 5 Conclusions From the data presented it may be concluded that a proper promotion of Ce-Ti oxide catalysts for NH3-SCR by tungsten requires the previous formation of W-O-Ti bonds because of a preference of the Ce-O-Ti over the Ce-O-W interaction, which may result in the segregation of bulk W oxide phases. This preference was supported by the observation that surface ceria species stabilize the anatase surface better than surface tungstate species. Tungstate interaction with the anatase surface induces Brønsted acid sites associated to tungstate, which may interact with ceria species in subsequent impregnation steps thus favoring the formation of Ce-O-W bridging sites. High activity may be obtained by enhancing the abundance of CeO-Ti and, in particular, Ce-O-W bridging sites accessible to the gas phase, avoiding bulk oxide phases as CeO2, and probably also TiO2 polymorphs. O 1s XPS signal intensity above 530.5eV often assigned as arising from reactive oxygen (“Oα”) and abundance of Ce3+ could not be correlated with SCR activity, neither could the abundance of Brønsted sites available, although Brønsted acidity may favor the SCR reaction without being integrated in the active sites. coredata.dc:description: The effect of tungsten on the activity of CeOx/TiO2 catalysts for the SCR of NO by NH3 was studied with catalysts of similar composition prepared via different impregnation routes from precursors used in industry. Reaction rates were related to structural and reactivity data collected by nitrogen physisorption, XRD, TPR, TPD of NH3, FT-Raman spectroscopy, DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3, and XPS. It was observed that proper promotion of Ce-Ti oxide catalysts requires previous formation of W-O-Ti linkages: while co-impregnation resulted in the segregation of bulk W oxide, probably because of a preference of the Ce-O-Ti over the Ce-O-W interaction, interaction of tungstate with anatase appears to induce Brønsted sites associated with W. These may interact with ceria species in subsequent impregnation steps thus favoring the subsequent formation of Ce-O-W bridges. High activity requires high abundance of Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-W bridging sites accessible to the gas phase, avoiding bulk oxide phases as CeO2, and probably also TiO2 polymorphs. On the other hand, O 1s XPS signal intensity above 530.5eV often assigned to reactive oxygen (“Oα”) and surface Ce3+ concentration could not be correlated with SCR activity, neither could be the abundance of Brønsted sites, though Brønsted acidity may favor the SCR without being integrated in the active sites.
coredata.dc:title: A close-up to the promoting effect of tungsten in Ce/TiO2 catalysts for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
